This is the main camp of the sewer's deep dregs. The altar in the middle is where Blip Bloop leads worship of The Duchess. Many deep dregs are going about daily business, some sit talking and eating, others perform daily tasks. In the room's center, several dregs are performing a worshiping chant.

items.name: Deep Dreg Leader
items.entry: Blip Bloop (use the game statistics for a {@creature merrow|XMM}) oversees the rituals here. If the characters were escorted in, he excitedly greets them. Otherwise, he defends his people. If reduced to half or fewer of his hit points, Blip Bloop flees into the sewers to return to the The Duchess.

items.name: Audience with Blip Bloop
items.entry: If the characters converse with Blip Bloop, he has the following information.

items: The Duchess is the deep dregs' god, and they worship her and believe she is planning a great storm that will drown the city of Drakkenheim and rid it of its filth.

He has a cauldron of bubbling mucus-like liquid before him and indicates the characters must drink from it as part of a welcoming ritual to cleanse them of their contaminants and allow them to speak to The Duchess. Anyone drinking the liquid must succeed on a DC13 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of contamination (see {@area appendix B|071|x}).
He explains that if they willingly take part in the ritual, they will have access to the smugglers' tunnel and can come and go as they please. All the deep dregs will know them as allies.

He proposes that the characters abandon their quest and defy any faction alliances. He instead suggests the dregs should continue to occupy this tunnel for which he will allow the characters continued use.

If the characters do not partake in the ritual but spare the deep dregs and pledge to keep their tunnel secret from the factions by reporting that nothing was found, Blip Bloop will be convinced to allow them to pass through the tunnels for now. However, with each future trip, Blip Bloop will encourage the characters to join them in their ritual.

items.name: Encampment Defense
items.entry: In addition to Blip Bloop, five deep dregs (use the game statistics of four {@creature Sahuagin Warrior|XMM|sahuagin} and one {@creature merrow|XMM}) also occupy this chamber and will defend it if they need to. A dozen other deep dregs in the area are non-combatants and flee into the sewers if a fight breaks out.

entries.name: Altar of The Duchess.
entries: The altar in the center of the encampment allows the dregs to communicate with The Duchess, and the characters can use this to interact with the entity as well. If the characters please Blip Bloop and prove themselves to the deep dregs, or if they defeat the creatures, they can place a hand upon the skull atop the altar to speak to The Duchess.

items.name: Touching the Skull
items.entry: A character touching the skull forges a connection with the Duchess, and they must succeed on a {@dc 15} intelligence saving throw or take 10 ({@dice 3d6}) psychic damage.

items.name: Failed Connection
items.entry: If a character fails their saving throw after touching the skull, they see visions of a great tidal wave sweeping over the city of Drakkenheim, and thousands of fish-like creatures devouring the buildings while tentacles of sea monsters pull and drag the city deeper below the waves. The character hears an incoherent whispering of some deep and eldritch thing clawing at their minds. Although they do not understand what is said, they are filled with a sense of utter dread and have nightmares of drowning and tentacles dragging them below a stormy sea for the next {@dice 1d4} days.

items.name: Successful Connection
items.entry: If a character succeeds on their saving throw after touching the skull, they have a vision of plunging deep below a stormy sea until all sunlight is gone and they float within a black, cold void. After a moment of nothingness, a distant light flickers into view, slowly drawing closer. Within the dark, a great face of a massive eel with jagged teeth and octarine eyes appears. It possesses a mane of tendrils ending in smaller eeled heads or tentacled arms writhing in rhythmic movements.

entries: The creature is the Duchess, and it speaks to the creature touching the skull. It will not reveal its true nature, or its motives, but will gleefully toy with the character speaking to it. The Duchess believes it is the true ruler of Drakkenheim, and its followers will be the harbingers of a rising tide that swallows the city. It tells the creatures to drink deep from the cauldron to be granted a gift of the depths, and that by doing so they will be able to walk amongst the ruins of the city without issue. It continues, indicating that their flawed and horrid flesh will no longer succumb to the contamination of the city, and that they will be able to withstand the coming storms, and the duchess will grant them peaceful passage within her domains.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: Characters who diligiently search the encampment can find {@area delerium|00d|x} crystal fragments worth a total of 100 gp, a {@item spell scroll|XDMG} of {@spell entangle|XPHB}, a {@item spell scroll|XDMG} of {@spell unseen servant|XPHB}, and a {@item potion of healing|XDMG}.

entries.name: 3f. Inner City Sewer
entries: An access hatch allows ready access to the Inner City surface should the characters wish to exit the sewers now.

entries.name: Area 4: Sally Port
entries: This location lies directly beneath Temple Gate, one of the five gatehouses leading into the Inner City. Here the city architects constructed a secret underground sally port: a place where defenders of the city could sneak out during a siege to strike behind enemy lines if needed. Unfortunately for the characters, it's sealed by a magically reinforced doorway.

On the surface, the gatehouse is occupied by deadly monsters hostile to any adventurers who dare approach. The opposite side of the sally port is accessed through the cellars in various guard posts within the city.

entries.name: Approaching the Sally Port

entries: As you travel through the sewers, you come upon an intersection where the sewer line meets a wide stone corridor. This passage is unlike those of the rest of the sewers—it is made of large broad flagstones and the sharp stonework of the walls are supported by a vaulted ceiling. Unlit torch sconces are hammered into the walls.
This passageway is approximately 20 feet wide and a hundred feet long, and connects the sewer line to the {@area Sally Port Antechamber|05c|x}.

There are no signs of recent passage down this hallway, nor are there any traps or hazards. An {@spell alarm|XPHB} spell was once present in this location to alert the City Watch captain posted to Temple Gate if anyone approached the sally port. However, the magic has long since faded, and none of the guards remain.

entries.name: Sally Port Antechamber

entries: The passage ends in a large, pill-shaped chamber supported by great stone pillars. Six leering statues carved to resemble terrifying creatures with draconic features and batlike wings decorate the room. Opposite the entrance corridor is an impressive gate.

Each of the six statues in this chamber are in fact {@creature Gargoyle|XMM|gargoyles} created to protect the sally port. Created by old magic placed by the city defenders, only two of the gargoyles can animate at a time. If a gargoyle is directly attacked or damaged, it animates to defend itself while its nearest neighbor also springs to life. Otherwise, the gargoyles do not attack unless characters interfere with the Sally Port Gate as described below.

entries.name: Sally Port Gate

entries: The Sally Port gate is a single formidable door crafted from solid metal and reinforced with bands of iron and steel. It is decorated with the intricate sigil of Drakkenheim: two dragons rampant flanking a castle with three towering spires. Flanking either side of the door, two large gargoyle statues loom ominously, their grotesque features carved with exquisite detail. Notably, the door shows no visible mechanism or handle on this side, and it sits flush with the surrounding stonework.

The gate is opened using a concealed winch and chain operated from the other side, which raises the door vertically. The gate slides down into place into a small gutter in the floor, creating a tight seal.
Not only is the gate physically formidable and difficult to destroy, it is warded with an {@b Arcane Glyph} trap and protected by the gargoyles statues, as described below.

Nevertheless, it's possible for the characters to open the Sally Port without fighting the gargoyles if they carefully disarm the Arcane Glyph trap and then successfully lift the gate. Resourceful characters who find magical treasures elsewhere in the sewers may be able to use those tools creatively to bypass the gate as well.

entries.name: Gargoyles
entries: Two of the {@creature gargoyle|XMM} statues in this chamber animate and attack if any of the following conditions are met:

items: The statues are directly attacked or damaged.
The Sally Port Gate is damaged, or an attempt is made to break it down or lift it up while the Arcane Glyph remains functional.
The Arcane Glyph trap on the door is activated or triggered.

entries: When a gargoyle is reduced to zero hit points, it magically crumbles to dust which then whirls through the air back to its original location, where it reforms after 24 hours. If the gate is still under attack, another gargoyle animates to take the place of the fallen creature.
The gargoyles do not pursue characters out of this chamber, nor pass through the Sally Port gate themselves.

items.name: Opening the Gate
items.entry: The winch used to open the gate is located on the opposite side, and is normally inaccessible for those approaching the {@area Sally Port|059|x} from the Outer City. Regardless, a character who makes it through to the opposite side can take a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to operate the winch, which opens the gate. The gate winch is on a mechanical timer that closes the gate automatically after 1 minute. A character can use a Utilize action to close the gate.

items.name: Damaging the Gate
items.entry: The Sally Port gate is a reinforced metal door. It can be attacked and destroyed. It has AC 19 and 72 hit points and is immune to poison and psychic damage. It is resistant to all other damage types except acid, force, and thunder.

items.name: Breaking the Gate
items.entry: Battering down the door is almost impossible. A character can spend an action to attempt a {@dc 30} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. On a success, the door shatters. On either a success or failure, the protective runes activate and two gargoyles animate to attack.

items.name: Bypassing the Gate
items.entry: Characters may have previously found a {@item potion of gaseous form|XDMG} or a {@item cape of the mountebank|XDMG} elsewhere in the sewer system if they've visited other locations. They can use those items (or related spells such as {@spell gaseous form|XPHB}, {@spell dimension door|XPHB}, or {@spell passwall|XPHB}) to get past the gate. Note that spells such as {@spell misty step|XPHB} require line of sight to their destination, so cannot be used to bypass the gate.

items.name: Lifting the Gate
items.entry: A character can use a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action and attempt a {@dc 20} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to lift the gate and hold it open until the start of their next turn, at which point they must use another action and succeed on the Strength check again to continue holding the gate open. If the character fails the check or decides not to repeat the action, they drop the gate. When they do, they can attempt to leap over to the other side by making a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a successful save, they may choose which side of the gate they end up on. On a failed save, the character remains on the side of the gate they were on when they picked it up. If the character fails the check by 5 or more, they are crushed under the gate (see below).

items: {@b Success at a Cost.} A character who fails the Strength test by only 1 or 2 can partially lift the gate but drops it after only a few moments. This is enough time that another character within 10 feet of them can use their reaction and make a {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check to dive through the opening. However, failing this check by five or more causes the character to be caught under the falling gate (see below).

items.name: Crushed Under the Gate
items.entry: A character who is under the gate when it closes takes 22 ({@dice 4d10}) bludgeoning damage, and becomes trapped under the gate. While trapped, they have the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} and {@condition Prone|XPHB} conditions, and take an additional 11 ({@dice 2d10}) bludgeoning damage at the end of each of their turns. A trapped creature can use the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action to attempt to escape on their own by making a successful {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Arcane Glyphs
entries: Each round when the gate first takes damage, the arcane runes etched upon it unleash a blast of magical lightning. The triggering creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 11 ({@dice 2d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

A {@spell detect magic|XPHB} spell reveals an aura of evocation magic upon the door. A creature within 5 feet of the gate can use a {@action Search|XPHB} action to examine it and make a {@dc 10} Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) check, detecting the tiny arcane runes etched upon the door with a success. Once the runes are found, a character can use the {@action Study|XPHB} action to make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check, which if successful reveals the glyphs mean "lightning."

Once the runes are identified, a character may spend a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action with a sharp tool, {@item dagger|XPHB}, or similar item to deface the glyphs by making a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check. Success disarms the trap without triggering it. On a failed check, the trap is still disarmed, but triggers one final time, and the character attempting to disarm the trap makes their Dexterity saving throw with {@variantrule disadvantage|XPHB}.

entries.name: Sally Port Exit
entries: On the other side of the gate is the winch used to operate it (described above). The passageway continues for another fifty feet before ending in a spiral staircase which leads to the surface in the Inner City, opening in the ruins of another guard post used by the City Watch.

entries.name: Part 5: Escape
entries: Depending on which faction the players choose to work with, they may exit the sewers at one of two locations. Both locations use the same city street map but represent two different locations in the city, either {@area Lantern's Way|065|x} in the Inner City, or {@area Dampstone Avenue|067|x} in the Outer City.

The player characters exit the sewers just as dusk settles in. A strange creature known as a {@creature lamplighter|DoDkSearchSmugglersSecrets} wanders nearby: a mutated aberration created when the eldritch energies of Delerium caused those who lit the streetlights to fuse with the lampposts.

entries.name: Inner City: Lantern's Way

entries: You emerge from the dark sewers amongst the cobblestone streets and densely packed buildings of the Inner City. You can make out the large foreboding city walls only a few blocks away. The city street you emerge on is dark. No lights are lit, no illumination to guide you back to the barracks. Dusk is setting in over Drakkenheim, you do not have much time before nightfall. The soft glow of lantern light shines from around a nearby corner. Perhaps the Hooded Lanterns are patrolling nearby?

This location is found south of the City Watch Barracks in the Inner City. The characters emerge from the sewers via a rather inconspicuous maintenance hatch nestled between a few ruined buildings along the city streets.
Although this is close to the Hooded Lanterns' main stronghold, it is out of the way enough that a dangerous monster still wanders nearby.
A {@creature lamplighter|DoDkSearchSmugglersSecrets} (see {@area appendix A|06d|x}) stalks the streets nearby, unless the characters do something to avoid it, the creature will spot them.

Careful characters may be able to sneak past or hide from the lamplighter and make their way to the Hooded Lanterns Barracks unnoticed. Doing so requires each character to make a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) check. Characters can gain advantage on these checks if they make good use of the urban environment or use their other skills or spells to create a distraction.

items.name: Signaling the Hooded Lanterns
items.entry: If the party fires the flare as they were instructed, the lamplighter immediately notices them and attacks. However, three Hooded Lantern {@creature Scout|XMM|scouts} show up three rounds later and help the characters defeat the monster.

entries.name: Outer City: Dampstone Avenue

entries: An old gravel road that stretches through dark abandoned houses lays before you as you peer out from the maintenance hatch. You seem to have come out on a side alley leading to a small square with an old well in the center. Amongst the ruins and abandoned houses are a series of unlit streetlamps, the street is dark as dusk falls. Rose should be here shortly; you just need to wait it out in the dark streets of Drakkenheim. A distant glow of lantern light catches your attention down the road—someone, or something, is making its way towards you.

items: This location is on the northern end of the spokes in the Outer City. A small maintenance hatch sits between the decrepit houses.

entries: If the characters agreed to meet {@area Rose Carver|028|x} here, she arrives just after sunset. The characters must wait for her arrival by the old well in the square.
A {@creature lamplighter|DoDkSearchSmugglersSecrets} (see {@area appendix A|06d|x}) is wandering towards the square to light the lanterns of the city and will attack the characters if it sees them.
Clever characters may be able to drive off or lure away the lamplighter while remaining hidden.
Rose Carver (human {@creature bandit captain|XMM}) and a pair of {@creature Thug||thugs} show up after three rounds and help the party defeat the lamplighter.

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: Characters who successfully survive the sewers and lost waterways of Drakkenheim might trigger the following developments.

entries.name: Scout's Honor
entries: If the player characters fire their flare and deliver the information to {@area Ansom Lang|01e|x} and the Hooded Lanterns, Ansom upholds his part of the bargain. He gives them a purse of 300 gold pieces and also awards them a writ of passage stamped by Lord Commander Elias Drexel, the leader of the lanterns. This writ allows the player characters to pass freely through Shepherd's Gate for future endeavors in the city.

If you are using this adventure as part of a larger Drakkenheim campaign, accomplishing this puts the characters in good standing with the Hooded Lanterns, and allows them to expand their foothold in the city. It also upsets the Queen's Men. Depending on your standing with them upon completion of the mission, they may send out a strike team or use a scheme against the party in an attempt to gain the intel on the {@area smugglers tunnel|049|x}, or acquire the {@area map|022|x} if it is still in the party's possession.

entries.name: Double Cross
entries: If the player characters choose to double cross the Lanterns and deliver the information to the Queen's Men, {@area Rose Carver|028|x} pays out half of what she promised the characters, offering them 100 gp and saying she will give them the other 100 gp promised once she and her gang verify their information. She claims there may be a bonus involved if the information is substantial for the gang's efforts in the city—she will even put in a good word with the Queen of Thieves.

If you are using this adventure as part of a larger Drakkenheim campaign, accomplishing this puts the party in good standing with the Queen's Men, and Rose Carver will uphold her part of the deal. She tells the player characters to come find her in Buckledown Row in a couple days. When they meet her there, she pays them each 75 gp for their efforts, and for opening a route for them to export {@area delerium|00d|x} right under the Hooded Lantern's feet. The Queen of Thieves may not let the characters right into her hideout, but Rose explains that the Queen is interested in their abilities and grants them the option to participate in her fighting pits to "prove their value."

If the player characters choose to lie about their findings to the Hooded Lanterns, whether the Lanterns believe them is up to the DM. Their reputation with the faction depends on if the Lanterns discover the truth of the double cross or not. If they do, the Hooded Lanterns become enemies of the player characters and immediately send a strike team to take them down.

entries.name: Honoring The Duchess
entries: If the player characters choose to lie to both factions and leave the tunnel undiscovered, their reputation with both factions is unaffected. Blip Bloop will let the players use the tunnels themselves whenever they want and leaves an open invitation for them to return so he can introduce them to The Duchess.

If you are using this adventure as part of a larger Drakkenheim campaign, Blip Bloop takes the player characters to The Duchess as promised and attempts to force them into serving her. This could lead to a disastrous situation as Blip Bloop wishes to change the characters into deep dregs to serve his master.

entries.name: Contamination
entries: Characters exploring Drakkenheim might be exposed to eldritch pollutants within the Haze or to arcane radiation emitted by delerium. These hazards cause a new condition called Contamination, which inflicts both debilitating symptoms and otherworldly mutations.

Contamination is measured in six levels. An effect can give a creature 1 or more Contamination levels, as specified in the effect's description. If an already-contaminated creature suffers another effect that imposes further Contamination, their current Contamination level increases by the amount specified in the effect's description.
In addition, each time a creature finishes a long rest while they have 1 or more Contamination levels, roll {@dice 1d20}. On a 1, the creature gains a Contamination level.
Upon reaching Contamination level 6 or higher, the creature transforms as described in the "Monstrous Transformation!" section.

entries.name: Contamination Symptoms
entries: A creature with the Contaminated condition suffers the symptoms from their current level as well as all lower levels:

1. No effect. 2. Hit points regained by expending {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} are halved. 3. No {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} are regained at the end of a long rest. 4. Damage dealt by the creature's weapon attacks and spells is halved. 5. The creature has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition. 6. The creature undergoes a monstrous transformation.

entries.name: Mutations
entries: In addition to suffering symptoms, each time a creature gains a Contamination level, roll {@dice 1d6}. If the result is equal to or less than the creature's current Contamination level, they gain a mutation. The Game Master can choose the mutation or determine it randomly by rolling on the Mutations table. If the result is the same as a mutation already affecting the creature, the GM chooses a different mutation or rolls again.

entries.caption: Mutations
rows: Rampant Mutation. Roll twice, ignoring this result on subsequent rolls.
Rasping. Your vocal cords warp. You can only speak in a halting gurgle. If you have 4 or more Contamination Levels, your tongue rots and falls out, and you can no longer speak.
Wasting. Your fingernails, teeth, and toenails start falling out. {@dice 2d6} fall out for each Contamination Level you have gained.
Rotting. Your lips, nose, and ears blacken and wither. If you reach 4 or more Contamination Levels, they rot and fall off. You can still speak and hear, however.

Molting. Painful blisters, welts, and multicolored lesions appear all over your skin, which burst and peel off painfully, exposing the raw sinew underneath. Once you reach 4 Contamination Levels, your skin entirely sloughs off.
Shedding. Each time you gain a contamination level, some of your hair falls out in patches. Once you reach 4 or more Contamination Levels, all hair on your body completely falls out.
Lambent Glow. You emit a dim octarine glow to a range of 10 feet. If you have 4 or more Contamination Levels, you instead emit bright light to a range of 30 feet.
Ocular Tumors. An eyeball opens somewhere on your body for each Contamination Level you have gained. If you have 4 or more Contamination Levels, you can see in all directions.
Spiked Growths. At the start of each of your turns, you deal 5 ({@dice 1d10}) piercing damage to any creature you are {@variantrule grappling|XPHB}.

Aquatic Adaptation. You sprout fish-like fins and gills. You gain a swimming speed equal to your land speed and can breathe underwater. If you have 4 or more Contamination Levels, you can only breathe underwater; but can hold your breath outside water for up to 1 hour.
Amorphous Form. Your bones and organs become gelatinous. You can move through a space as narrow as 6 inches wide without squeezing.
Chitinous Skin. Shell-like growths appear all over your body, giving you a +1 bonus to AC. If you have four or more Contamination Levels, this bonus increases to +2.
Cyclopean Vision. Your eyes merge into a single central eye which can emit an energy beam as a ranged spell attack using your Intelligence modifier. If it hits, it deals {@damage 2d6} radiant damage.
Spatial Displacement. You can cast {@spell misty step|XPHB} once for each Contamination Level you have gained. You regain these uses when you finish a {@variantrule long rest|XPHB}.
Tentacled Limb. One of your arms becomes a fleshy tentacle. When you make a melee attack on your turn, increase your reach by 5 feet.
Spider Climb. You gain a climb speed equal to your walking speed. You can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.
Whispering Voices. You gain {@variantrule telepathy|XPHB} to a range of 10 feet, but other people hear it as their own voice. If you have 4 or more Contamination Levels, the range extends to 60 feet.
Belly Maw. A toothy mouth appears on your stomach, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with it, you deal piercing damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + your Strength modifier.

Eyeless Sight. Your eyes become milky orbs, and you gain {@sense blindsight|XPHB} to a range of 10 feet. If you have 4 or more Contamination Levels, your eyes rot out, and dim octarine light burns in the sockets. Your blindsight increases to 30 feet, but you are blind beyond this radius.

Arcane Blood. You gain an additional spell slot of the highest level you can cast (to a maximum of 5th level). If you don't have spell slots, your hit point maximum increases by an amount equal to your level. If you have four or more Contamination Levels, you gain two spell slots instead of one or increase your hit points by twice your level.

entries.name: Removing Contamination
entries: Only specific magic can remove Contamination levels. Creatures do not recover naturally. The {@spell purge contamination|DoDk} spell (detailed below) can remove Contamination, but it leaves affected characters with the {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} condition. A {@spell heal|XPHB} spell removes all Contamination levels and mutations from a contaminated creature.

An effect which removes a Contamination level also removes one randomly determined mutation. All Contamination symptoms end and all mutations are removed if a creature's Contamination level is reduced below 1. Skin, hair, fingernails, and toenails lost to mutations regrow normally once all Contamination levels are removed. However, a {@spell regenerate|XPHB} spell or similar magic is needed to restore any other body parts (such as teeth, limbs, or eyes) lost as a result of Contamination levels. Appendages or limbs which develop as a result of mutations wither and fall off when Contamination levels are removed, and other warped body parts are restored to their original form.

entries.name: Death and Dying while Contaminated
entries: When a Humanoid with any Contamination levels dies, they animate 24 hours later as a {@creature haze husk|DoDk} (use the {@creature zombie|XMM} stat block). A creature with six or more class levels or {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB| Hit Dice} rises as a {@creature wight|XMM} instead.
Being raised from the dead reduces a creature's Contamination level by 1.

entries.name: Monstrous Transformation!
entries: A creature who reaches Contamination level 6 or higher triggers a transformation into a horrific monster controlled by the Game Master. Once triggered, the transformation finishes in 1 round and is thereafter permanent. Game Masters are encouraged to narrate a suitably gory description of the transformation. The Game Master chooses the creature's new form, which is most often an aberration or monstrosity of some kind, such as a gibbering mouther. The new form usually has a {@variantrule Challenge Rating|XPHB} similar to that of the original creature or to the creature's class levels, but under appropriate circumstances, you can choose a Challenge Rating that is much higher or much lower.

The creature's game statistics are entirely replaced by those of the chosen monster. The creature assumes the new form's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice}. All Contamination levels are removed from the creature, though the GM can grant additional traits to the new form similar to any beneficial mutations gained from Contamination levels.

The GM determines what remains of the original creature's personality and memories, if anything. Regardless, the creature is invariably driven mad by the transformation and remains under the GM's control.

entries.name: Purge Contamination
entries: At the GM's discretion, the following spell can be learned by any spellcaster for the purposes of the adventure. For a more challenging adventure, the {@spell purge contamination|DoDk} spell is unknown to the characters, and only Flamekeeper Hanna in {@area Emberwood Village|018|x} has access to it.
